title: Georgia House - Day 25 (2026-02-28)
summary:
Here is a structured summary of the Georgia House session transcript from 2026-02-28:

**Overview**
The session featured a notable speech by Rabbi Adam Star, who discussed the importance of standing up against bigotry and intolerance, drawing parallels to the story of Queen Esther from the Book of Esther. The Rabbi emphasized the need for lawmakers to use their positions to help those in need and make the world a better place.

**Key Actions**
No major bills were passed or referred during this session.

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**
No new bills were introduced.

**Notable Moments**
- Rabbi Adam Star delivered an inspirational speech, calling on lawmakers to speak up against hatred and injustice, like the biblical figure Queen Esther.
- Representative Esther Panage introduced Rabbi Star and discussed the significance of the upcoming Jewish holiday of Purim.

**Votes**
No recorded votes were mentioned in the transcript.

**Attendance**
The transcript notes that the Speaker urged all members to come to the floor and take their seats. The doors were closed to maintain quorum.

**Adjournment**
The transcript does not explicitly state when the session adjourned or provide information about the next scheduled session.

All members, all members, if you're pleased, come to the floor. All members come to the floor. We'll see if we can get going here. I think rules are still meeting. We'll see if we can get going. All members, all members, will please come to the floor and take this seats. Mr. Clerk, will you ring the bell? We're going to dispense with the roll call at this time. All members, all members, come to the floor and take your seats. Doors will please close the doors. We'll close those doors and keep them locked. Please, and you can just keep them closed. As is our custom, we will begin our day with scripture reading and prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. I enjoyed meeting our chaplain this morning, and I'm sure you're going to enjoy his message today. Our chaplain this morning, we'll be introduced by the lady from the 51st House District, Representative Esther Panage. Representative Panage. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Shalom, y'all. Come on. Shalom, y'all. Thank you. Rabbi Adam Star has served as the Rabbi and Spiritual Leader of Congregation or Hattara in Atlanta since 2008. Under his leadership, the congregation has grown in membership and built a brand new state-of-the-art synagogue, the first Orthodox synagogue in the world, constructed from the ground up, according to environmentally sustainable standards. Rabbi Star received his rabbinical ordination from the Rabbi Isaac Elkhunan Theological Seminary at Yashiva University in New York. He has served as the Executive Committee of the rabbinical Council of America and as a past President of the Atlanta Rebinnical Association. While Rabbi Star is not my congregational Rabbi, he is a friend and a teacher. And he also was the one who put up the Mizzosa on my office door post. A Mizzosa is a parchment inscribed with Hebrew verses. Come by and visit, and I'll be happy to show you the Mizzosa. Please welcome Rabbi Adam Star. Thank you. Shalom. Good morning, esteemed representatives. It is an honor to stand before you today as the chaplain of the day and to open this session with words of prayer and inspiration. Thank you to my dear friend, Representative Esther Penich, for this special honor and invitation. As you will soon hear, Esther's strong and courageous leadership carries on the legacy of her biblical namesake, Queen Esther. In just a couple weeks time, Jewish people around the world will be reading the whole Maghilla from the skull scroll of Esther and celebrating the joyous holiday we call Poros. The poem's story recalls a time when the Jewish people scattered throughout the Persian Empire, faced an existential threat. Haman, the King's advisor, devised a genocidal plan to annihilate the Jewish people simply because they were different. He cast lots or purim to determine the date of their destruction, believing that fate was on his side. But fate was not the deciding force. Courage was our heroine, Queen Esther, who had hidden her Jewish identity, was called upon to risk her own safety and life by outing herself as a Jew. To plead to her husband, King Ahashveroch, for her people's survival. She was initially hesitant, but her cousin Mordechai urged her with these powerful words that ring so true today. For if you remain silent at this time, relief and deliverance will perish from the Jews from another... Relief and deliverance will arise from the Jews from another place, but you and your father's house will perish. And who knows if it was for such a time as this that you attained royalty upon hearing this, Esther spoke up with courage and moral clarity there by saving the Jewish people from genocidal annihilation. This verse reminds us that there are moments in history when silence is not an option, when injustice threatens the vulnerable, when evil seeks to destroy, we are called to act with moral courage. Today, this lesson resonates very deeply. The story of Porum reminds us that hatred against any people left unchecked can lead to violence and death. It is a call to all of us to stand up against bigotry in any form. But today, I speak on behalf of my people and your Jewish constituents, we are not okay. We have been reeling since October 7, 2023 with the brutal murders, rape and abductions of our Israeli brethren by the blood-filled hands of Hamas. Those painful wounds were reopened this week with the return of the dead bodies of the Bebas family, of mother Shiri and her young children, children, queer aged four, and Ariel, who was less than a year old, who were brutally murdered with bare hands by Hamas, returned to be buried by their father Yardin, who was just released a couple weeks ago after 500 years, 500 days of being hostage, being held hostage in Gaza. And there are still 59 innocent hostages who remain in captivity in Gaza, including American citizens, brutally torn from their families enduring unimaginable anguish. We are also witnessing a frightening rise in anti-Semitism across the world, even here in Georgia, and especially across college campuses in this very country. We cannot be silent. Their plight is a painful reminder, our plight is a plain painful reminder that hatred and violence still exist in our world. Like Esther, we must raise our voices on their behalf, and I implore you to let your Jewish constituents hear your voice in our time of pain. The Georgia homegrown hero and prophetic voice of Dr. King taught the world and I quote, In the end, we will remember not the words of our enemies, but the silence of our friends. Your voice means so much to us more than you can ever imagine. Please rise and let us pray. Almighty God, source of justice and mercy, we turn to you in these halls of law and justice. Grant wisdom and strength to the leaders gathered here that they may govern with compassion and a steadfast commitment to righteousness. May they, like the biblical hero Esther, recognize the power of their positions to bring hope and healing to those in need. May we never be silent in the face of evil. May we stand together, people of all faiths and all backgrounds united against bigotry and intolerance and hatred. May you make the world a better place by best serving the people you are here to represent. Bless this great state of Georgia and all who labor to uphold the values of freedom, dignity and justice. In the face of darkness, may we be bearers of light. In the presence of hatred, may we stand for love and peace. May we each recognize that like Queen Esther, perhaps we have been placed in this place and position for such a time as this. And let us say, Amen. We will now turn and recite the pledge of allegiance to the United States of America. We will now turn and recite the pledge of allegiance to the United States of America and to the Republic of which it stands when nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.
